>From: Colin Green <cgreen@...>
> >
> >What's unfortunate is that when it died, the new topology created to 
>replace
> >it wasn't based on the one that died.
> >
>Normally this is desired behaviour. If a species hasn't improved for
>some time then that can be taken as an indication that the species
>represents a local optimum and therefore should be abandoned. If you
>want to give the species more of a chance then it's probbaly more valid
>to increase the time to species death.

That depends on your definition of 'species'.  For everybody but me, a 
species can represent more than one network topology.  Thus, it can continue 
to improve through the addition of more topology.  I don't do that.  I treat 
each distinct topology as a separate species.  Improvement within a topology 
can come only through weight mutation.  Once a topology reaches its optima, 
time to move on, time to add (or remove) topology.  But how you move on can 
make a lot of difference.

Basically, I didn't want to mess with 'speciation' which is why I opted for 
treating each topology as a distinct species.
